Invited Talk Galois: High Assurance Software John Launchbury Galois Connections Inc Beaverton, OR, USA 
john@galois.com Abstract As a company, Galois began its life with the mission simply of supplying functional 
programming services, building tools and products for clients, leveraging the productivity of functional 
languages and the abilities of our engineers. This went well, except that our business lacked focus. 
Every new job had to be found and sold from scratch. We realized that we had to focus on a specific market 
if we wanted to achieve stability and growth. We chose High Assurance Software as it was a natural fit 
both for our technology and our expertise, further narrowing our attention to information assurance (IA). 
Why IA? Because there are challenging assurance requirements here for which functional languages and 
other semantics-based techniques can be very relevant, especially in the handling of information that 
cross security classification boundaries. Currently there are very few systems that are trusted enough 
to span from unclassified to secret, so many US government employees have to have two or three separate 
computers on their desk, each connected to totally disconnected networks that each exist at a single 
classification level. Information is kept separate by air gaps and sometimes it doesn t get through 
to the people who need it. To be permitted to span multiple classification domains, a system must satisfy 
many stringent engineering and assurance requirements, including the application of formal and semi-formal 
techniques. The challenges we had to confront in maturing Galois as a company such as the need for focus, 
and the importance of brand, for example provide powerful lessons that may be relevant to the broader 
functional language community as it continues to seek wider acceptance of its tools and technology. Bio 
John Launchbury is a founder and CEO of Galois Connection Inc. His business interest is to lead a world-class 
organization that is able routinely to deliver high-assurance software to clients, addressing the many 
complexities that arise in practice. In his other life he is a Professor in Computer Science, on entrepreneurial 
leave from the OGI School of Science and Technology at OHSU. John gained his Ph.D. from Glasgow University, 
winning the British Distinguished Dissertation prize. John s primary technical interest has been in the 
development of functional programming, focusing especially on semantics and semantic-based transformations.
